titleStmt.title: A new binary salp swarm algorithm: development and application for optimization tasks

analytic.title: A new binary salp swarm algorithm: development and application for optimization tasks

biblStruct.note: Received: 6 April 2018 / Accepted: 23 June 2018 Ó The Natural Computing Applications Forum 2018

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Salp swarm algorithm (SSA) is one of the recent meta-heuristic algorithms that imitate the behaviors of salps during the navigating and foraging in oceans to perform global optimization. However, the original study of this algorithm was proposed to solve continuous problems, and it cannot be applied to binary problems directly. In this paper, a new binary version of the SSA named BSSA is proposed based on a modified Arctan transformation. This modification has two features regarding the transfer function, namely multiplicity and mobility. By this modification, the exploration and exploitation capabilities can be enhanced. The proposed BSSA is compared among four variants of transfer functions for solving global optimization problems. Also, a comparative study with different binary algorithms including binary particle swarm, binary bat algorithm and binary sine-cosine algorithm on twenty-four benchmark problems is conducted. Furthermore, the nonparametric statistical test based on Wilcoxon's rank-sum is carried out at 5% significance level to judge statistically the significant of the obtained results among the different algorithms. The results affirm the superior performance of the modified BSSA variant over the other variants as well as the existing approaches regarding solution quality.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Binary optimization problem (BOP) is denoted as binarybased problem space that represents an important class of the combinatorial optimization problems. It has practical and theoretical importance as it is employed largely in several practical applications such as facility location (including emergency vehicles, health centers and commercial bank branches) and scheduling tasks (budgeting, flexible manufacturing systems, telecommunications, mass transit services, and wind turbine placement) [1][2][3]. Also some of its applications in assignment tasks include knapsack problem [4], resource allocation problem [5,6], dimensionality reduction [7], feature selection [8][9][10], network optimization, unit commitment, and cell formation [11,12]. This type of problems is well-known NP-hard in a strong sense.

Many traditional methods have been developed to solve BOP involving enumeration schemes such as relaxation methods, Lagrangian techniques, branch-and-bound methods, reduction schemes and integer programming [13,14]. Unfortunately, these methods are time-consuming and have been designed to solve low-scaled problems. Since the practical problems are characterized by larger dimensions and riddled with many local optima, the exhaustive search can be deteriorated. Further, the non-differentiability and discontinuity of the optimization cannot be handled with the deterministic methods. Due to these occupied limitations in the deterministic methods, more and more researchers have been focused on the meta-heuristic algorithms inspired from specific phenomena.

Meta-heuristic optimization algorithms are a family of algorithms that involve stochastic operators [15]. This means that these algorithms contain some random operators in the seeking process of obtaining the global optimal. The main reason behind their flourishment in many applications lies behind some advantages such as simplicity, local optima avoidance problem and derivation independency [16].

Some examples of meta-heuristic optimization algorithms are: Genetic Algorithms (GA) [17], Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) [18], Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) [19], and Differential Evolution (DE) [20]. On the other hand, some examples of the recent algorithms are: Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) algorithm [21], Cuckoo Search (CS) algorithm [22], Gravitational Search Algorithm (GSA) [23], Charged System Search (CSS) [24], Firefly Algorithm (FA) [25], Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) [26], Colliding Bodies Optimization (CBO) [27] algorithm, Crow Search Algorithm (CSA) [28], Sine Cosine algorithm (SCA) [29,30] and among other [31][32][33][34][35][36][37][38].

Salp swarm algorithm (SSA) [39] is one of the most recent algorithms in the field of meta-heuristic algorithms. It is inspired by the behavior of salps for navigating and foraging in oceans. Salps live in the deep of oceans, and they often form a swarm called salp chain. This algorithm has been proven for its capability for solving the optimization problems with continuous real search spaces [39].

The purpose of this paper is introducing a new binary variant of salp swarm algorithm (BSSA) for solving general binary optimization problems. Five binary variants of the BSSA are proposed based on five transfer functions. The fifth variant represents the modified one, where in this version, the Arctan transformation is modified to obtain a flexible global search regarding two features, multiplicity and mobility. The modified Arctan transformation can enhance exploration-exploitation capabilities. The performance of the variants is investigated by applying it on 24 benchmark problems. The results affirm that the modified variant is the best one and outperforms the other variants as well as the comparative algorithms in most cases.
The main contributions of this study are as follows:

(1) BSSA algorithm is developed for solving general binary optimization problems. In BSSA, transfer function is proposed for mapping the continuous search space to the binary search space. (2) Five variants of BSSA based on various transfer functions are developed and simulated extensively on several optimization problems. In this sense, the observed characteristics of modified BSSA variant which employed the Arctan transfer function affirms its superiority among all variants. (3) The proposed method exhibits two features, namely multiplicity and mobility. The multiplicity aims to enhance the exploration ability, while the mobility is responsible for improving the exploitation capability. (4) The effectiveness of the BSSA variants is demonstrated by the comparisons on 24 benchmark problems, where the superiority of the modified BSSA variant is investigated.

This article is structured as: at first, the preliminaries of the salp swarm algorithm (SSA) are studied in Sect. 2. Subsequently, the proposed versions of binary SSA (BSSA) are provided in Sect. 3. The experimental results and the discussions are reported in Sect. 4. In conclusions, main remarks are reported in Sect. 5.

div.head: Overview of SSA
div.p: Salp swarm algorithm (SSA) is a new meta-heuristic algorithm introduced by Mirjalili [39]. It mimics the navigating and foraging in deep oceans. The transition from real inspiration is discussed in following sections.

div.head: Inspiration
div.p: Salps are species of Salpidae family that live in deep oceans. They are similar to jelly fish in their tissues and movement. Salps are moved by the pumped water through the body as propulsion to move forward. The main interesting behavior of salps lies behind their swarming behavior that is they often form a swarm called salp chain. This chain can assist to achieve better locomotion during the foraging process.

div.head: Artificial SSA
div.p: SSA is a new swarm algorithm that is inspired by the collective behavior during navigating and foraging in oceans. These salps are arranged as chain shape called salp chain that helps in achieving better locomotion during the foraging. The salp chain behavior has been modeled mathematically [39] by dividing the population into two groups: leader and followers salps. The front of the chain is considered as the leader salp, while followers are the rest of the salps. Thus, the leader salp guides the swarm, and the followers follow each other (and leader directly or indirectly). Similar to other swarm algorithms, SSA starts its optimization process by initializing a set of multiple salps with random positions. Then, the fitness of each salp is determined, and the best position among all salps is assigned by the variable F as the source food to be chased by the salp chain. Afterward, these salps update their positions by two phases, namely leader phase and followers phase. For the leader salp, the position is updated as follows:
div.formula: x 1 j ¼ F j þ c 1 ub j À lb j À Á c 2 þ lb j À Á c 3 ! 0:5 F j À c 1 ub j À lb j À Á c 2 þ lb j À Á c 3 \ 0:5 &ð1Þ
div.p: where x 1 j is the position of the leader salp (first one), F j is the position of the food source in the jth dimension,ub j ; lb j are the upper and lower bounds in the jth dimension, respectively, and c 1 , c 2 , c 3 are random numbers that are generated uniformly in the interval of [0,1].

Equation (1) shows that the leader only updates its position concerning the food source. The coefficient c 1 presents a significant parameter in SSA because it is responsible for balancing exploration and exploitation search and it can be defined as follows:
div.formula: c 1 ¼ 2e À 4t T ð Þ 2ð2Þ
div.p: where t denotes the current iteration and T is the maximum number of iterations.
For each follower salp, the position is updated as follows:
div.formula: x i j ¼ 1 2 x i j þ x iÀ1 jð3Þ
div.p: where i ! 2 and x i j is the position of follower salp in the jth dimension. Algorithm 1 presents the pseudo code of the traditional SSA.

3 The proposed binary schemes of the SSA In the traditional salp swarm algorithm (SSA), salps continuously update their positions to a cretin positions in the search space by considering the lower and upper bounds. In combinational optimization problems such as binary optimization, the solution is restricted to the binary {0, 1} values that motivates to propose a binary version of the SSA. In this work, a novel binary salp swarm algorithm (BSSA) is proposed for the binary optimization tasks. The salps update their positions by using Eqs. (1) and (2) for leader and follower, respectively. In the BSSA, the pool of solutions is represented by binary strings of {0, 1} values. According to this aspect, the positions of a salp is updating through 0-1 flipping operation. This flipping process is performed by a certain threshold value that is related to the transfer function. In this work, we have investigated the performance of some transfer functions through introducing different variants of BSSA as follows.

div.head: Binary scheme based on Tanh transformation (BSSA-I)
div.p: In this binary scheme, BSSA-I, a tangent hyperbolic transfer function is employed to update the salp position, where this function works as a threshold limit for the switching the position between 0 and 1. To map real-valued continuous position into a binary one, the tangent hyperbolic transfer function is adopted and it denoted by Tðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ:
div.formula: Tðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ ¼ tanhðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ ¼ e ð2x j i ðtþ1ÞÞ À 1 e ð2x j i ðtþ1ÞÞ þ 1ð4Þ
div.p: According to this function, the position is updated as follows:
div.formula: D j i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ 1 if Tðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ [ k 1 0 Otherwise &ð5Þ
div.p: where k 1 is a random a random number uniformly distributed over 0 and 1.

div.head: Binary scheme based on sigmoidal transformation (BSSA-II)
div.p: The second binary scheme of the BSSA (BSSA-II) examines the sigmoidal transfer function for mapping process of the real-valued continuous position to binary representation. The sigmoidal transfer function is denoted by Sðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ:
div.formula: Sðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ ¼ Sigðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ ¼ 1 1 þ e Àx j i ðtþ1Þð6Þ
div.p: Regarding this transformation, the position is updated as follows:
div.formula: D j i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ 1 if Sðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ [ k 2 0 Otherwise &ð7Þ
div.p: where k 2 is a random a random number uniformly distributed over 0 and 1.

div.head: Binary scheme based on modified sigmoidal transformation (BSSA-III)
div.p: The third binary scheme of the BSSA, BSSA-III, is established based on modified sigmoidal transfer function that is expressed as follows:
div.formula: MSðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ ¼ MSigðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ ¼ 1 1 þ e À 10ðx j i ðtþ1ÞÀ0:5Þð8Þ
div.p: By this transformation, the position is updated as follows:
div.formula: D j i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ 1 if MSðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ [ k 3 0 Otherwise &ð9Þ
div.p: where k 3 is a random a random number uniformly distributed over 0 and 1.

div.head: Binary scheme based on Arctan transformation (BSSA-IV)
div.p: The fourth scheme of the BSSA, BSSA-IV, utilizes the Arctan transfer function for mapping process of the realvalued continuous position to binary representation. The Arctan transfer function is denoted by Aðx j i ðt þ 1Þ:
div.formula: Aðx j i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ 2 p arctan p 2 x j i ðt þ 1Þð10Þ
div.p: Regarding this transformation, the position is updated as follows:
div.formula: D j i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ 1 if Aðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ [ k 4 0 Otherwise &ð11Þ
div.p: where k 4 is a random a random number uniformly distributed over 0 and 1. By observing the performance of the above schemes, we can find some weakness; meanwhile, the salp positions can be stuck at certain local points and remain unchanged with larger values. To avoid this weakness, a modified Arctan transformation-based multiplicity and mobility concepts are introduced to oblige the salp positions to diverse their positions with highest values.

div.head: Binary scheme based on modified Arctan transformation (BSSA-V)
div.p: In this scheme, the Arctan transformation is tweaked to achieve high performance. This transformation has two features, multiplicity and mobility. The multiplicity aims to the diversity of solutions by depressing threshold value to a certain limit, and it can enhance the exploration ability as in Fig. 1a, while the mobility is responsible for switching in the neighborhood of the obtained best so far, and then it can improve the exploitation trend as in Fig. 1b. The modified Arctan transfer function is denoted by MAðx j i ðt þ 1Þ:
div.formula: MAðx j i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ 2 p arctan p 2 x j i ðt þ 1 À v j Qð12Þ
div.p: where
div.formula: v j ¼ F j þ 0:5 Â ðx j I À x j II Þ, x I ;
div.p: x II are two solutions selected randomly.Regarding this transformation, the position is updated as follows:
div.formula: D j i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ 1 if MAðx j i ðt þ 1ÞÞ [ k 5 0 Otherwise &ð13Þ
div.p: where Q ¼ 0:1 $ 3, k 5 is a random a random number uniformly distributed over 0 and 1.

The mechanism of mapping the search space to space is illustrated in Fig. 2. Figure 2 shows the process of mapping from the continuous space to binary space, where three columns are presented in this figure. The first one indicates the solutions in the continuous search space, and the third column illustrates the solutions in the binary search space, while the intermediate column exhibits the proposed transfer function that is responsible for mapping process from the continuous domain to a binary domain. Also, the transfer function aims to change the bit of the position vector from 0 to 1 and vice versa as a probability manner. In this figure, the lower arrow shows that solution starts at the first column and ends at the third column by the means of the transfer function as in the intermediate column. The steps of the pseudo code for the binary SSA (BSSA) are presented in Algorithm 2. Based on Algorithm 2, it can be seen that the structure of the proposed BSSA consists of three main processes. The first phase starts with the initialization process, where the solution is switched from 0 or 1 and vice versa according to uniform random number. The second phase represents the evaluation process, where the solutions are evaluated to determine the best one among them (leader). The third phase operates with updating the algorithm parameters as well as the solutions, where the each parameter is updated according its adopted form while the updating of solution is performed by a certain threshold value that is related to the transfer function. In addition, we denote the BSSA algorithm as BSSA-I when k = 1, BSSA-II when k = 2, BSSA-III when k = 3, BSSA-IV when k = 4, and BSSA-V when k = 5. The BSSA-V represents a modified version of BSSA-IV, and this is the first work about the SSA to solve binary optimization problems. In addition, the numerical results addressed in the next showed that our BSSA-V is better than the different variants, especially for solving the large-scale problems.

div.head: Benchmark tests
div.p: In this section, we compare the proposed binary versions of the salp swarm algorithm (BSSA) with the binary algorithms such as binary particle swarm (BPSO), binary bat algorithm (BBA) and binary sine-cosine algorithm (BSCA), using a set of benchmark functions as in Table 1. Many various kinds of optimization tasks were covered by these test instances [16], where they are specified into four groups as follows:

• Group I-Unimodal tests: the function nature contains a single minimum. Functions F 1 to F 7 belong to this group. In this work, the continuous test function is handled as a binary problem where each dimension is encoded by K-bit binary string such that first bit for the sign of the number, the subsequent L bits for the integer part and the final K-L-1 bits for a fractional part of the number. The values of K and L were chosen for each test function according to range values of the number. For example, for the test F 1 , we used K = 10 and L = 7, where the problem is handled with binary strings until the termination condition is satisfied. Afterward, each of these K-bit strings is converted into a real number, and the fitness value is computed.

div.head: Experiment settings
div.p: In this subsection, the settings for the proposed method and the other comparative algorithms are presented in Table 2 as the reported in the corresponding literature. Each algorithm is tested 20 independent run with the same maximum number of iterations for each run.

div.head: Results and discussion
div.p: The comparisons of three algorithms (BPSO, BBA and BSCA) and five variants of BSSA algorithm are investigated. The overall results showed that modified variant of BSSA (BSSA-V) outperformed the other three algorithms (BPSO, BBA and BSCA) and two variants of BSSA (BSSA-II and BSSA-III) in all tests. Also, the proposed BSSA-V outperforms the BSSA-I in 12/18 functions and BSSA-IV in 10/18 functions. The results for all algorithms and BSSA variants are recorded in Table 3. Furthermore, the convergence performance is demonstrated in Fig. 3, where the rate of BSSA-V is faster than the other three algorithms and other variants for all benchmark functions. It has very fast converged for all functions, especially in

div.p: ½À600; 600 F 16 ð0Þ ¼ 0 Additionally, some statistical measures are determined to investigate the stability of the proposed versions. From Table 3, it can observe that the proposed BSSA-V variant has the better results for means and standard deviations in most cases. On the other hand, the box plot is portrayed for all algorithms and different variants as in Fig. 4. Based on the observed results, it can conclude that the proposed BSSA-V has a good quality and stability than the others. Based on the convergence graphs of the test functions and their box plots that are depicted in Figs. 3 and4, respectively, three significant conclusions can be drawn. Firstly, BSSA provides best convergence speed on almost selected functions, and also it performs better than the other comparative algorithms, which means that the incorporation of multiplicity and mobility has significant impact on the performance of BSSA. Secondly, in the view of the box plots graphs, the BSSA provides stable solutions on almost selected test functions, which implies the reliability of solutions, especially for the large-scale instances. Lastly, most results of the BSSA exhibit a continuous improvement during optimization process, which affirm that the BSSA can alleviate the sucking in the premature convergence.
div.formula: F 17 ¼ À20 exp À0:2 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi 1 30 P 30 i¼1 x 2 i q À exp 1 n P n i¼1 cosð2px i Þ À Á þ 20 þ
div.p: The comparison between the best variant (BSSA-V) and other algorithms that are taken from Jiang et al. [40] is recorded in Table 4. Table 4 shows that the proposed BSSA-V outperforms the BHPSOWM in 10/18 test functions, outperforms PSO in 14/18 test functions and outperforms GA in 16/18 test functions. Based on the obtained results, it is concluded that the proposed BSSA-V has promising results for binary schemes.

Additional the proposed variants of BSSA are investigated on six composite functions (category IV) that are taken from [41]. The results of the different variants of the BSSA and other compared algorithms for this category are recorded in Table 5. Among the different variants, the modified one (BSSA-V) performed better than the other variants as well as the compared algorithms. Further, the convergence performance is depicted in Fig. 5, where the proposed BSSA-V has the faster rate than the other variants and other algorithms. The box plot is depicted for this category as in Fig. 6. In sum, the proposed BSSA-V has a superior performance for most benchmark functions.

div.head: Performance assessment
div.p: In this subsection, Wilcoxon-signed rank test (WRT) [42] is employed to assess the performances. It is a nonpara- • Record the results of pair algorithms such as the proposed BSSA-V and another algorithm over all tests. • Compute ranks, positive ranks R ? and negative ranks R -for tests in which the proposed BSSA-V dominates the algorithm X, and dominated by the algorithm X, respectively. • Compute the p value that dedicates significance level of the statistical test using hypothesis testing, where the lower the p value, the stronger the evidence against H 0 . • Interpret results. Tables 6 and7 show the obtained results through implementing the WRT for pair-wise comparisons between BSSA-V and the other variants of the BSSA (i.e., BSSA-I, BSSA-II, BSSA-III, BSSA-IV) as well as other algorithms. From these results, we can conclude that the BSSA-V has a superior performance over the other variants and the other algorithms.

According to the comprehensive study and comparisons among the BSSA variants, we can state that the modified Arctan transfer function variant has merit superiority of the results and high performance among other binary variants. In this context, the advantages behind this high performance are due to two reasons: (a) BSSA combines merits of multiplicity and mobility which can make the balance between exploration and exploitation capabilities. By these merits, the local optimal can be avoided and then convergence rate toward the global optimum can be accelerated. (b) The modified transfer function based on v-shape obliges the solution to switch its position when it sucked in unpromising area of the search space. Thus, this feature implies the efficient running of the algorithm.
